Comments: This solution presents a model for predicting plastic waste and determining the optimal recycling method for different cities. It uses linear regression for waste prediction and considers single-stream, dual-stream, and drop-off recycling. The model includes calculations for costs, budget, and truck fleet conversion. The response is well-structured and provides clear explanations.

Q1.Definition: Predict the amount of discarded plastic which will either be recycled or be placed in landfills.
Assumption: All plastic waste not recycled goes into a landfill. The amount that reaches other destinations is negligible.
Plastic production and recycling increase at a linear rate as time passes, based on an extrapolation of the data found.

Q1.Results: Approximately 357.39 million tons of plastic waste will go to landfills during the years 2013-2023. This would take up 2644.68668 million cubic yards of space.
Q1.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly performed, but the linearity assumption is acknowledged as a potential source of error.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Uses linear regression, a standard statistical technique.
Strength: Clearly presents the equations and calculations.

Q2.Definition: Proposing a New Recycling Program in Three U.S. Cities (Fargo, North Dakota; Price, Utah; Wichita, Kansas).
Assumption: The easier the program is for the individual, the more likely he or she is to recycle regularly.
Every person in any given city pays taxes as required by law.
The transportation costs involved in any recycling plan are negligible compared to the costs of operation and the installation costs.
The proposed recycling system will be designed independently of any existing system.
The cost of travel between stops on a recycling truck's route is insignificant compared to the costs of running the program itself.
The cost of processing the recycled material and the prices of both diesel and electronic trucks will remain constant over the years.
Q2.Model: Calculates cumulative cost of running each program (single-stream, dual-stream, drop-off) based on population, waste generation, recycling rate, installation cost, and cost per ton. Compares this to a budget based on tax revenue. Calculates surplus budget and truck fleet size and conversion from diesel to electric.
Results: Price, Utah: Drop-off recycling, complete at year 15.
Fargo, North Dakota: Dual-stream weekly recycling, complete at year 26.
Wichita, Kansas: Single-stream weekly recycling, complete at year 17.
Q2.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly performed, but the model considers different program types and ranks them based on desirability.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Comprehensive model considering various factors and costs.
Strength: Includes a plan for converting to electric trucks.
Strength: Provides specific recommendations for each city.
Weakness: Several assumptions about costs and behavior.
Weakness: Population density was not taken into account.
Weakness: Bigger cities might need more than one facility

Q3.Definition: Expanding the Propositions to Apply on a Nationwide Level
Q3.Assumption: Implicit assumption that the model developed for the three cities can be applied nationally.
Q3.Model: Applies the model to individual cities, using benchmarks for debt payoff, electric truck conversion, and program completion.
Q3.Results: The model can be used to select the most efficient program for any given U.S. city, with benchmarks for financial feasibility and environmental benefits.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Provides a clear plan for national application.
Strength: Sets benchmarks for program success.
Weakness: Relies on the assumptions and limitations of the city-level model.
Weakness: Does not address regional variations or specific challenges of a national rollout.
